qas.question: What did many Presbyterian churches introduce as a result of modifying prescriptions?

answers.text: hymnody, instrumental accompaniment, and ceremonial vestments

qas.question: What is favored by most American Presbyterian churches that is semi-formal service for the "lords Day"?

plausible_answers.text: introducing hymnody, instrumental accompaniment, and ceremonial vestments into worship

qas.question: How did Holy Week churches modify the prescriptions?
Most Lord's Day churches observe which holidays?
What do many Lutheran churches incorporate into communion services?
What type of lectionary do Anglicanism churches follow?

plausible_answers.text: Advent, Christmas, Ash Wednesday, Holy Week, Easter, Pentecost, etc.

qas.question: Although Presbyterians do not observe holy seasons they do observe which holidays?

context: Over subsequent centuries, many Presbyterian churches modified these prescriptions by <b3_0>introducing <a0_0>hymnody, instrumental accompaniment, and ceremonial vestments<a0_0/> into worship<b3_0/>. However, there is not one fixed "Presbyterian" worship style. Although there are set services for the "Lord's Day", one can find a service to be evangelical and even revivalist in tone (especially in some conservative denominations), or strongly liturgical, approximating the practices of Lutheranism or Anglicanism (especially where Scottish tradition is esteemed),[clarification needed] or semi-formal, allowing for a balance of <a1_0>hymns, preaching, and congregational participation<a1_0/> (favored by probably most American Presbyterians). Most Presbyterian churches follow the traditional liturgical year and observe the <b4_0>traditional holidays<b4_0/>, holy seasons, such as <b7_0>Advent, Christmas, Ash Wednesday, Holy Week, Easter, Pentecost, etc.<b7_0/> They also make use of the appropriate seasonal liturgical colors, etc. Many, incorporate <b5_0>ancient liturgical prayers and responses<b5_0/> into the communion services and follow a <b6_0>daily, seasonal, and festival<b6_0/> lectionary. Other Presbyterians, however, such as the Reformed Presbyterians, would practice a <a2_0>cappella exclusive psalmody<a2_0/>, as well as eschew the celebration of holy days.
